title: Clinton voted for almost every trade deal, killed millions of jobs, says Sanders.
text: The race between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders broke out this week after rhetorical chatter about who was or was not eligible for the presidency. It began when Clinton said on Wednesday that Sanders "didn't do his homework and was talking for more than a year about doing things he obviously didn't really study or understand." In response to an article published by the Washington Post, which commented that Clinton questioned his qualifications, Sanders re-fired, saying that Clinton was the unqualified person who disturbed Clinton's supporters and the former President's husband. On Friday, when Sanders withdrew his statement and said, "Sure," Clinton was qualified. But Sunday at the press meeting, Sanders said his point of view all along that Clinton lacked good governance. The impact of employment is unclear. The debate about the impact of business transactions on employment has been going on for decades, and the jury is still abroad. On the one hand, trade unions and some left-wing think tanks often link the loss of American jobs to the expansion of trade. The advocates objected to the agreements of Chile and Singapore, which, in their 2003 report, stated that they would eliminate an unspecified number of jobs. The Liberal Economic Policy Institute has found that the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) has cost the United States more than 800,000 jobs and South Korea has been dealing with some 60,000 jobs. In a 2014 report, the Research Centre reported that the United States lost 3.2 million jobs between 2001 and 2013 due to trade with China. On the other hand, business groups argue that business transactions actually promote employment. For example, a 2010 United States Chamber of Commerce report found that the 14 business transactions in 2008 supported 5.4 million jobs. At the same time, the United States-China Business Council and the Financial Times argue that the loss of manufacturing jobs was not due to trade with China as much as the gains in technology and productivity, as well as the result of a more sophisticated economy. In recent fact-finding, we have found numerous non-partisan reports that show that NAFTA has not resulted in any significant loss of jobs or job gains. The analysis carried out by economists at the University of Tafts and the University of Michigan did not expect any net impact on employment from the transactions of Chile, Singapore and South Korea.
